------=_NextPart_000_017C_01CA3ADE.7D47F920
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi guys,

I am trying to replicate the "hard" learning problem from the beh=
avioural diversity papers that have recently been discussed on the mailing =
list. I have a few ideas I would like to try out, but I would like to be ab=
le to compare them to the original research to see if I can get any improve=
ment.

I have two questions to ask of those of you who have tried recreatin=
g this:

1. How big is the area? I have got all of the internal "walls" in =
place in scale to the total size of the map, however I would like to get a =
rough idea of the width/height of the "map". I understand that this should =
all be relative, but without some sort of "scale factor" for my map from th=
e original I don't know what is a reasonable amount of space for the agent =
to move etc. Currently my world is 120 x 115 units big, and the agent can m=
ove anywhere up to 2.5 units per time period.

2. I also am interested in h=
ow the outputs of the neural network are interpreted. I know from the paper=
s that there are two output neurons, one for forward/backward and one for l=
eft/right. Currently I am interpreting these as output < 0.5 =3D turn left,=
 output > 0.5 =3D turn right and the same for forward/backward. This is lea=
ding to a pretty constant behaviour of moving in circles around the map, al=
ways turning left - so I am wondering how other people have interpreted the=
 output result to get a more intelligent movement pattern.

Thankyou for yo=
ur time,

Aidan
------=_NextPart_000_017C_01CA3ADE.7D47F920
